Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Investigating the Ultimate Mechanisms of Embodied Cognition

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration:
To date, relatively little success has been achieved in realizing machines that continually perform simple yet adaptive behaviors in unstructured environments (compared to a structured environment such as a factory). The prevailing approach to create such machines is to copy physiological and neurological systems observed in animals, and build them into robots. This raises the issue however of what from among the infinitude of existing biological structures should be copied. Research under this award is pursuing an alternative approach: rather than copy existing biological systems, evolutionary dynamics are copied and connected in a virtual space. The resulting evolutionary algorithm optimize virtual robots' neurological structures that control behavior and their body plans. Importantly, evolution in these studies is task and behavior specific.

The research is intended to make important contributions to robotics and biology. For roboticists, this work will enable computers to automatically design the body plans and neural controllers for robots that are more adaptive and robust than robots designed manually. Automatically-designed virtual robots can then be built as physical devices and deployed into real-world environments, to include those that are dangerous to humans. For biologists, our studies will provide insight into why and how particular structures evolved in nature. For example, if legged robots originally evolved for locomotion are then selected to locomote and grasp objects, computational evolution may re-purpose the robot's front legs into arms and grippers; or, it may add manipulatory appendages onto the existing body plan. Either outcome would be of great interest to evolutionary biologists.

Finally, experiments are being housed in online tools that will allow graduate, undergraduate and K-12 students to run evolutionary simulations passively on their own machines, as well as actively participate in the process: they may design novel virtual environments in which the robots must evolve. This active participation is intended to motivate students to understand the physics, biology, engineering and computational processes underlying evolution.

POR.DRECONTENT:
In this award, we investigated how the power of evolution can be harnessed to help us automatically design helpful machines. We created computer programs that would simulate virtual worlds, populate them with robots, and then simulate evolution: robots that performed more interesting, complex, or helpful behavior outcompeted less competent, or more dangerous machines, driving the latter to extinction. Along the way, we learned a great deal about how *biological* evolution may have shaped bodies and brains to create increasingly intelligent organisms. More specifically, we learned that robots that change their shape (like frogs from tadpoles, or butterflies from caterpillars) are easier to evolve than robots that maintain the same form throughout their lifetimes. We also learned that if evolution is allowed to dictate the body of the robot, along with its brain, we can often evolve useful machines must more easily than if a human builds the robot body and computers evolve brains for it. We also learned that, in some cases, people and computers can team up to design robots together, and that such a hybrid team does better than just people making robots, or computers making robots.


In the last two years of the award we also turned to evolving soft robots. Soft robots are capable of doing things rigid machines aren’t, like squeezing themselves through narrow gaps in disaster sites to search for human survivors. Or, perhaps one day, to navigate the blood stream looking for tumors or clots.


In addition to our research, we also developed many tools to help the public get involved in robotics. We created an online course called ‘Ludobots’ (*ludo* means *play* in Latin) where students can create robots, even if they don’t know how to write code.  The course will continue to run even after this award terminates: the course is available at www.reddit.com/r/ludobots. For those who do know how to code, we created Pyrosim, a [Py]thon [Ro]botics [Sim]ulator: ccappelle.github.io/pyrosim. We also created a simple app in which people can work together to design robots: it’s available at www.goo.gl/utc1qo.


Throughout this award, we visited dozens of schools, Maker Faires, technology expositions and other community events to spread the wonder of robotics. We did our best to help students, young and old, find ways to participate in the technological revolution going on around us.
